climbs.name: Working for Peanuts
climbs.fa: Ward Smith, Chris Smith & Dave Quinn, 2/94

content.description:
On the far right side of the Sunny and Steep wall sits a low angle, thin slab. While nowhere near as steep as its neighbors, Working for Peanuts is a good way to get things going or warm things down before/after the long hike. 

  Begin just left of the first bolt. Climb up a very serious and tricky start to gain some easier climbing above. Hold on tight up through the second bolt and stay on those feet, work right a bit and follow the most prominent features passing three more generously spaced bolts to a chain anchor.
content.protection: Five bolts and a chain anchor.
content.location: Working for Peanuts is on the far most right side of the wall, and just right of a shallow chimney.

climbs.name: Turtle Wax
climbs.fa: Dave Quinn, Ward Smith & Chris Smith, 2/94

content.description: Between Scorpions and Sunny and Steep is a steep overhanging crack to face. Climb the crack, then break right to the face as the route gets steeper. Pull a roof up higher and move to the Sunny and Steep anchor.
content.location: Immediately left of Sunny and Steep

content.description: Begin below a low roof.  Pull the roof and continue to the steep, stiff, fingery crux.  Then face-climb to the top.  Holds have broken on this route making it a bit harder since the FA.
Overhanging face which climbs out a series of roofs before the crux and up the head wall. The climbing is not straight forward as you use slopers, pockets, edges, and heel hooks.
content.protection: The route is well protected clipping six bolt en route to the fixed anchors.
content.location: The route is the first route left of the main chimney (5.8) as you are looking directly at the wall.  Start under the series of roofs and lower off of the anchors at the top.

content.description: This route climbs the bulge left of Tour de Pump.  protected by 6 bolts.
Climb out the overhang and up the face on the second bolted line right of the chimney.
content.protection: 6 glue in bolts to two bolt anchor.

climbs.name: Sport Chimney
climbs.fa: Chris Smith, Ward Smith & Steve Wood, 2/94

content.description: The big chimney in the middle of the wall. Described as a "Traditional, bolt-protected chimney experience". Crux is the final move getting into the chimney proper.

From Handren, 2016 guidebook... Start 8' left of Mr. Choads and follow a left-learning seam to an anchor. No star rating in the guidebook for this route, so giving it 1 star as a starting point since the book is typically stingy with stars.
content.location: From Handren, 2016 guidebook... Start 8' left of Mr. Choads and follow a left-learning seam to an anchor.

content.description: A new route with a bit of everything: pockets, open hand jugs, and lost of edging.  Begin as for Gimme Back My Bullets and climb up the steep face clipping the first bolt to the left.  Move left on to edges and a pocket or two, then up the wall to the anchors of the 5.8.    A bit harder than Bullets, a bit easier than Tour De Pump.
content.protection: 6 bolts, shares anchors with the 5.8 chimney.
content.location: This new route (fall of 2010) is located between the 5.8 chimney and Gimme Back My Bullets.

climbs.name: Scorpions
climbs.fa: Chris Smith, Ward Smith, Leslie Smith & Paula King, 2/94

content.description: A fun route up the dihedral left of Sunny and Steep. Power up the overhanging dihedral and the work the delicate face above to a two bolt anchor with tow hooks for lowering.

climbs.name: Peak Performance
climbs.fa: Chris Smith, Ward Smith & Dave Quinn, 2/94

content.description: Right behind the large boulder on the right side of the wall. Climbing through a big hueco to a thin bulgy crux. Hard.
A long, sustained, technical climb unlike the other climbs at Sunny And Steep.
content.location: Around the corner to the right of the main area, 2nd route to the left of the chimney.

content.description: Juggy goodness up to the second bolt then some tricky beta to pull through to the top. Fine example of a sunny and steep route for this area.
content.location: Obvious route on the boulder 50 yards from the main sunny and steep wall. Same location as Edward Silverhands.

content.description: This route climbs a steep overhanging face as it follows a seam up jugs, and slopers to a pumpy crux at the top.
content.protection: This route is well protected with 6 bolts and fixed anchors.
content.location: Second route right of the obvious chimney in the middle of the main wall.

content.description: A decent route to warm up on when at the Sunny and Steep wall.  Good holds heading almost straight up the face.
content.location: About 50 yards west of the Sunny and Steep wall is a large boulder with two routes on it.  This is the route on the south face.

climbs.name: Claimjumpers Special
climbs.fa: Ward Smith, Chris Smith, Leslie Smith & Paula King, 2/94

content.description:
Full force for the rating, this is a great route to do while at the crag. Varied in style, this line offers a lot more than steep jug pulling. Demanding precision and a good amount of thought Claimjumpers Special will keep you thinking.  

  A dead vertical beginning leads to some difficult and hard to read terrain. A tight break, hidden edges, and few nice side-pulls keep the climbing entertaining. Pull through its low-lying committing crux to a quick rest and enjoy a more technical, more mellow dash to the chains.
content.protection: Five bolts to a two-bolt anchor.
content.location: Claimjumpers Special is the far-most left route at the wall. It starts steep and rounds out on a more featured face.

climbs.name: Cirque de Soleil
climbs.fa: Paula King, Ward Smith & Steve Wood, 2/94

content.description: Another long, technical climb that is unlike the routes around the corner.  This one is slightly easier than Mr Choad's because there are a couple of good rests before and after the crux.
content.protection: 10 bolts, shares anchors with Mr Choad's

content.description:
Another of the less popular, more crimpy, routes on the left side of the wall.   

  A reasonable start leads to a huge move to an even more huge hold.  Then you set up for a very difficult crux with another big move.    

  Rating is sort of a wild guess - I messed up the crux and never did really get it right:  so if you have done this before and have an opinion on the difficulty, please toss it in here.
content.location: One route left of Scorpions, overall the 3rd route in from the left side of the wall.

content.description:
Nice line, but not as popular as many of the routes at this wall.   Unlike many of the routes here, this route is not juggy - it is sort of slightly overhanging with some crimps and big moves.    

  So on the whole, it appears most folks prefer "Sunny and Steep" and some of the other routes to the right - but this is a worthwhile line and worth a spin.  Good movement with high points for continuity.
content.location: This is one route right of Claim Jumpers Special, overall the second one in from the left side of the wall.

content.description: A popular and inviting sport crag home to about twenty routes ranging in grade from 5.10 to 5.12 and length from ~ 40' to 100'.  As the name implies the crag receives sun from about mid morning till dusk and many of the routes are steep and thuggy.  With an ample flat area below the cliff and bombproof glue-in bolts thanks to some of the same people who developed much of Rumney, many find Sunny and Steep an enjoyable destination away from the loop.
